questiontext.text:
A tennis ball is struck by a racket at an angle of 10o to the horizontal, giving it an initial speed of 18 m/s.

How high will it go?

{1:NUMERICAL:=0.5:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

How far will it travel horizontally before being contacted by the opponent's racquet at the same height from which it was struck?

{1:NUMERICAL:=11.3:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

(Give your answers in m correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)



(Question ID #1).

generalfeedback.text:
First let's look at the $$y$$ component.

Final velocity, $$v$$, is zero at the maximum height; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$18\cdot sin(10)$$; acceleration, $$a$$, is equal to the constant, $$g$$.

Rearranging and applying $$v=u+a\cdot t$$ gives:

$$t=(v-u)/a=(0-(18\cdot sin(10))/-9.8)=0.3$$ s.

Next, applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$s=(3.1\times0.3)+(0.5\times -9.8\times0.3^2)=0.5$$ m.


Next, let's look at the $$x$$ component.

Acceleration, $$a$$, is zero; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$18\cdot cos(10)$$; and the time over which the ball travels before it hits the opponent's racquet is $$2\cdot t$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$s=(2\times18\cdot cos(10)\cdot0.3)=11.3$$ m.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image adapted from 'http://www.costadelsol-holidays.com/userfiles/images/sport/tennis_court.jpg'

hint.text:
HINT

Use the SUVAT equations of motion on both the $$x$$ and $$y$$ components of the tennis ball's motion to solve this question.

Final velocity, $$v$$, is zero at the maximum height; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$26\cdot sin(14)$$; acceleration, $$a$$, is equal to the constant, $$g$$.

Rearranging and applying $$v=u+a\cdot t$$ gives:

$$t=(v-u)/a=(0-(26\cdot sin(14))/-9.8)=0.6$$ s.

Next, applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$s=(6.3\times0.6)+(0.5\times -9.8\times0.6^2)=2$$ m.


Next, let's look at the $$x$$ component.

Acceleration, $$a$$, is zero; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$26\cdot cos(14)$$; and the time over which the ball travels before it hits the opponent's racquet is $$2\cdot t$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$s=(2\times26\cdot cos(14)\cdot0.6)=32.4$$ m.

How far will it travel horizontally before being contacted by the opponent's racquet at the same height from which it was struck?

(Give your answers in m correct to 1.d.p.)

(Question ID #45).

generalfeedback.text:
First let's look at the $$y$$ component.

Final velocity, $$v$$, is zero at the maximum height; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$22\cdot sin(15)$$; acceleration, $$a$$, is equal to the constant, $$g$$.

Rearranging and applying $$v=u+a\cdot t$$ gives:

$$t=(v-u)/a=(0-(22\cdot sin(15))/-9.8)=0.6$$ s.

Next, applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$s=(5.7\times0.6)+(0.5\times -9.8\times0.6^2)=1.7$$ m.


Next, let's look at the $$x$$ component.

Acceleration, $$a$$, is zero; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$22\cdot cos(15)$$; and the time over which the ball travels before it hits the opponent's racquet is $$2\cdot t$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$s=(2\times22\cdot cos(15)\cdot0.6)=24.7$$ m.

Final velocity, $$v$$, is zero at the maximum height; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$17\cdot sin(13)$$; acceleration, $$a$$, is equal to the constant, $$g$$.

Rearranging and applying $$v=u+a\cdot t$$ gives:

$$t=(v-u)/a=(0-(17\cdot sin(13))/-9.8)=0.4$$ s.

Next, applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$s=(3.8\times0.4)+(0.5\times -9.8\times0.4^2)=0.7$$ m.


Next, let's look at the $$x$$ component.

Acceleration, $$a$$, is zero; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$17\cdot cos(13)$$; and the time over which the ball travels before it hits the opponent's racquet is $$2\cdot t$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$s=(2\times17\cdot cos(13)\cdot0.4)=12.9$$ m.

{1:NUMERICAL:=0.4:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

How far will it travel horizontally before being contacted by the opponent's racquet at the same height from which it was struck?

{1:NUMERICAL:=8.6:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m

(Give your answers in m correct to 1.d.p.)

(Use a value of g of -9.8 m/s2)



(Question ID #89).

generalfeedback.text:
First let's look at the $$y$$ component.

Final velocity, $$v$$, is zero at the maximum height; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$15\cdot sin(11)$$; acceleration, $$a$$, is equal to the constant, $$g$$.

Rearranging and applying $$v=u+a\cdot t$$ gives:

$$t=(v-u)/a=(0-(15\cdot sin(11))/-9.8)=0.3$$ s.

Next, applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$s=(2.9\times0.3)+(0.5\times -9.8\times0.3^2)=0.4$$ m.


Next, let's look at the $$x$$ component.

Acceleration, $$a$$, is zero; initial velocity, $$u$$, is $$15\cdot cos(11)$$; and the time over which the ball travels before it hits the opponent's racquet is $$2\cdot t$$.

Applying $$s=u.t+\frac{1}{2}.a.t^2$$ gives:

$$s=(2\times15\cdot cos(11)\cdot0.3)=8.6$$ m.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
